nexttext: where $g$ is the g-factor, $\mu_B$ is the Bohr magneton, $\tau_{\pi}$ is the $\pi$ pulse length (100 ns), $\hbar$ is the reduced Planck constant, $B^{(i)}_{\sigma}$ is the amplitude of the $\sigma =$ clockwise or $\sigma =$ counterclockwise circularly polarized $\vec{B_{1}}$ components, respectively, and $B_{1,CPW}^{(i)}$ is the microwave magnetic field due to the CPW resonator at spin $i$ \cite{hoult1997}. The $B_{1,CPW}^{(i)}$ term in this expression is proportional to the spin-to-resonator coupling \cite{malissa2012}. $B^{(i)}_{1,\sigma}$ is described in terms of $\vec{B}_{1,D}$ and $\vec{B}_{1,CPW}^{(i)}$ and their relative phase difference $\phi$ as
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="E_{f,a}^{(i)}\propto B_{1,CPW}^{(i)}sin(\frac{g\mu_{B}\tau_{\pi}}{2\hbar}B^{(i%
)}_{1,\sigma})^{3}" display="block"><mrow><msubsup><mi>E</mi><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>a</mi></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>∝</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>B</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>W</mi></mrow></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>B</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>τ</mi><mi>π</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">ℏ</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>B</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>σ</mi></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: where $+$ corresponds to clockwise and $- $ to counterclockwise polarizations. The overall signal of each transition is simply given as a sum over each individual spin's contribution such that
prevtext: where $g$ is the g-factor, $\mu_B$ is the Bohr magneton, $\tau_{\pi}$ is the $\pi$ pulse length (100 ns), $\hbar$ is the reduced Planck constant, $B^{(i)}_{\sigma}$ is the amplitude of the $\sigma =$ clockwise or $\sigma =$ counterclockwise circularly polarized $\vec{B_{1}}$ components, respectively, and $B_{1,CPW}^{(i)}$ is the microwave magnetic field due to the CPW resonator at spin $i$ \cite{hoult1997}. The $B_{1,CPW}^{(i)}$ term in this expression is proportional to the spin-to-resonator coupling \cite{malissa2012}. $B^{(i)}_{1,\sigma}$ is described in terms of $\vec{B}_{1,D}$ and $\vec{B}_{1,CPW}^{(i)}$ and their relative phase difference $\phi$ as
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="B^{(i)}_{1,\sigma}=\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{|\vec{B}_{1,D}|^{2}+|\vec{B}_{1,CPW}^{(i)}%
|^{2}\pm 2|\vec{B}_{1,D}||\vec{B}_{1,CPW}^{(i)}|\cos\phi}" display="block"><mrow><msubsup><mi>B</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>σ</mi></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msqrt><mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>B</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msubsup><mover accent="true"><mi>B</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>W</mi></mrow></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>±</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>B</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msubsup><mover accent="true"><mi>B</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>W</mi></mrow></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>ϕ</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mrow></math>
